article.data-sblg-tags: featured realdessert cheesecake cheesecakechallenge noprotein kladdkaka espresso lafiancee coffee mudcake chocolate regular nonhealthy fromageblanc marscapone whitechocolate

header.aside: From the Cheesecake Challenge I present you the most sinfully delicious and decadent dessert I've ever made: White Chocolate Cheesecake on an Espresso-kladdkaka (Swedish sticky mudcake) base. This Lila, Chop! "non-healthy" recipe is an exception.

section.p:
Hence the third Lila, Chop! protein cheesecake recipe on this blog, and the first recipe made in our new kitchen in Toulouse, France.
A perfect, single-portion protein cheesecake cupcake.

There are three main ingredient differences in this recipe: Following traditional New York cheesecake recipes, I replaced ground almonds with (gluten-free) graham crackers in the base (note: I learned for the first time in my life that it's pronounced gram crackers and not gray-ham crackers!) I also used fromage frais (fresh, soft cream cheese) whipped into mousse and flavoured with vanilla, which I found in the French supermarket, Monoprix.

tr.td: cream cheese, kesella, craime fraiche, or a mix of all these
Myprotein Micellar Casein, vanilla cake batter, or
any vanilla whey or casein protein powder
Sweet Freedom natural dark sweetener , or

section.p: I decided to try making my own strawberry jam for the cheesecake topping. I caramelised fresh strawberries using Sweet Freedom natural dark sweetener, a 100% fruit-based liquid sweetener, entirely free of artificial flavouring, colouring or preservatives and suitable for diabetics. The result was a sweet, sticky strawberry topping that went very well together with the creamy cheesecake.

tr.td: Mix all the base ingredients together in a bowl.
Form base layer by pressing the mix evenly down into 8 cupcake forms.
Put aside strawberry halves and liquid sweetener for topping.
Mix all the cheesecake ingredients in a bowl, making sure there are no lumps left.
Pour the cheesecake filling into cupcake forms on top of cheesecake base.
Bake at 160'C (320'F). Be careful not to over-bake cheesecake! It will harden as it cools, so you want it to still be mushy and wobbly inside when you remove it from the oven.
Whilst the cheesecake is in the oven, mix strawberry halves, lemon zest and liquid sweetener in a saucepan. Cook on low heat for 20-minutes, until caramelised.
Once both the cheesecake and topping have cooled, place strawberry topping on cheesecake cupcakes.
Taste this heavenly creation, but ideally refrigerate cheesecakes for a couple of hours before devouring.

figure.figcaption: A heavenly bite of strawberries 'n cream cheesecake.

section.p: This recipe makes eight cupcakes, and macro-nutrient information is per slice. To make the recipe leaner, simply use 0% Greek yoghurt instead of the 2%, quark instead of cream cheese, and sugar-free syrup instead of the fruit/honey/agave-based liquid sweetener. To make the recipe sweeter, add more syrup to the base and 2-4 tbsp of coconut palm sugar to the cheesecake batter.

This recipe was adapted from Proteinpow's recipe Maple, Butterscotch & Dark Cherry Protein Cheesecake by Anna Sward. Notice how the difference in certain key ingredients, albeit subtle, results in an overall significantly different cheesecake as compared to my last two: Tahini Cheesecakeini and Choco-Cherry Cheesecake Corfetti.

figure.figcaption: Lila the sous-chef & pastry-taster, in the inauguration of our new kitchen.
